113.issueTitle: This is an application for an early end to the tenancy as it would be unreasonable, or unfair to the landlord or other occupants to wait for a Notice to End Tenancy for Cause to take effect
113.textDescriptionTitle: Please describe why you require an early end to the tenancy
113.noticeMethodTitle: How will you serve within 1 day?
113.issueHelp:
As this is an urgent application, failure to submit required and recommended evidence with your application may result in your application being dismissed. Evidence may include photos, witness statements, written communications, audio or video recordings, police file numbers any other evidence to support that the tenant is an immediate threat to life or property.

The Notice of Dispute Resolution must be served to each respondent within 1 day of receiving it from the Residential Tenancy Branch. Service options include: in person with a witness, post to the door with a witness, by registered mail or by email. You may serve the Notice Package by email only when the other party has clearly agreed to accept documents by email.

123.issueTitle: I issued a 10 Day Notice to End Tenancy for unpaid rent not paid in the required time and I want an order of possession
123.textDescriptionTitle: Describe why possession of the unit is being requested
123.issueHelp:
If the tenant disputes this notice, the application cannot be determined through the direct request process and must be determined in a hearing with the tenant's application.

Ensure you have read the information on the second page of the notice carefully - it includes a list of evidence that you include with your application.If you are submitting your application too early, your application will be dismissed.

You must provide evidence below to support your possession claim including proof that the tenant has not paid rent when due.

124.issueTitle: I issued a 10 Day Notice to End Tenancy for rent and/or utilities not paid in the required time and I want an order of possession
124.textDescriptionTitle: Describe why possession of the unit is being requested
124.issueHelp:
You must give the tenant a written demand letter before issuing this notice informing the tenant of the amount of utilities owing and the due date, allowing the tenant 30 days to pay the unpaid utilities.

If the tenant disputes this notice, the application cannot be determined through the direct request process and must be determined in a hearing with the tenant's application.

Ensure you have read the information on the second page of the notice carefully - it includes a list of evidence that you must include with your application.

If you are submitting your application too early, your application will be dismissed.

You must provide evidence below to support your possession claim including proof that the tenant has not paid rent and/or utilities when due.

125.issueTitle: I issued a 10 Day Notice to End Tenancy and I want a monetary order in addition to an order of possession for rent not paid in the required time
125.textDescriptionTitle: Describe why possession of the unit and money is being requested
125.issueHelp:
The money that you are requesting must be for unpaid rent only and must be the same as the amount on the 10 Day Notice to End Tenancy that you served to the tenant.

If the amounts do not match, you may wish to seek an order that the tenant move out through the participatory process by returning to the previous step and changing your issue there.

Your tenancy agreement must be signed and state the amount of rent and the day it is due.

126.issueTitle: I issued a 10 Day Notice to End Tenancy and I want a monetary order in addition to an order of possession for rent and/or utilities not paid in the required time
126.textDescriptionTitle: Describe why possession of the unit and money is being requested
126.issueHelp:
The money that you are requesting must be for unpaid rent and/or utilities only and must be the same as the amount on the 10 Day Notice to End Tenancy that you served to the tenant.

If the amounts do not match, you may wish to seek an order that the tenant move out through the participatory process by returning to the previous step and changing your issue there.

You must provide evidence below to support your possession claim including proof that the tenant has not paid rent and/or utilities when due. Your tenancy agreement must be signed and state the amount of rent and the day it is due and indicate that utilities are not included in the rent.

102.selectionTitle: I issued a 10 Day Notice to End Tenancy for Unpaid Rent or Utilities not paid in the required time
102.issueTitle: I issued a 10 Day Notice to End Tenancy for Unpaid Rent not paid in the required time and I want an order of possession
102.textDescriptionTitle: Describe why possession of the unit is being requested
102.selectionHelp: This notice is used if the tenant fails to pay all the rent and/or utilities that are due on the day it is due. If the tenant owes utilities and a 30 day demand letter was issued for the payment of the utilities, select "Utilities only or Rent and Utilities."
102.issueHelp:
If you file your application too early, it may be dismissed. Verify that you can apply for possession now.

Ensure you have read the information on the second page of the notice carefully.

You must provide evidence below to support your possession claim including proof that the tenant has not paid rent when due.

104.selectionTitle: I issued a One Month Notice to End Tenancy for Cause or End of Employment
104.issueTitle: I issued a One Month Notice to end tenancy for cause (not end of employment) and I want an order of possession
104.textDescriptionTitle: Describe why possession of the unit is being requested
104.selectionHelp: This notice is given if you believe the tenant or the tenant's guests have done something to cause the tenancy to end or if the rental unit or site is provided as part of the tenant's employment and the tenant's employment has ended. If this notice was not given as part of an employment arrangement, select "For Cause."
104.issueHelp:
If you file your application too early, it may be dismissed. Verify that you can apply for possession now.

Ensure you have read the information on the second page of the notice carefully.

You must provide evidence to prove the cause(s) on the notice.

101.issueTitle: I issued a One Month Notice to end tenancy for end of employment and I want an order of possession

103.selectionTitle: I issued a Two Month Notice to End Tenancy for Landlord's Use of Property or Because Tenant Does Not Qualify for Subsidized Rental
103.issueTitle: I issued a Two Month Notice to End Tenancy for Landlord's Use of Property and I want an order of possession
103.textDescriptionTitle: Describe why possession of the unit is being requested
103.selectionHelp: This notice is used if you will be using the property for your own use or because the tenant does not qualify for a subsidized rental unit. If you are not a public housing body that charges rent according to a tenant's income, select "Landlord's use of the property."
103.issueHelp:
If you file your application too early, it may be dismissed. Verify that you can apply for possession now.

Ensure you have read the information on the notice carefully.

You must provide evidence to prove that you intend in good faith to use the property as stated on the notice.

105.issueTitle: I issued a Two Month Notice to End Tenancy - Tenant Does Not Qualify for Subsidized Rental Unit - and I want an order of possession
105.textDescriptionTitle: Describe why possession of the unit is being requested
105.issueHelp:
If applicable, provide evidence to show that the notice is not valid.

You must submit your application within 15 days of receiving this notice. If you file your application too late, the landlord may request an order of possession. Verify that your dispute deadline has not passed.

Ensure you have read the information on the notice carefully.

130.selectionTitle: I issued a 12 Month Notice to End Tenancy for Conversion of Manufactured Home Park
130.issueTitle: I issued a 12 Month Notice to End Tenancy for Conversion of Manufactured Home Park
130.textDescriptionTitle: Describe why possession of the unit is being requested
130.selectionHelp: This notice is used if you will be converting a manufactured home park to another use.  You cannot submit your application until after the tenant deadline for disputing the notice has passed.
130.issueHelp:
If you file your application too early, it may be dismissed.

The tenant must dispute this notice within 15 days of receiving it. To determine when you can make your application, you must consider how you served the notice and when documents served in that manner are deemed received. For example, if you served the notice by attaching it to the door, it is deemed received three days after it was served.

Ensure you have read the information on the second page of the notice carefully.

You must provide evidence to prove that you intend in good faith to convert the manufactured home park to another use.

106.selectionTitle: The tenancy agreement states the tenant will vacate the rental unit or site at the end of the fixed term
106.issueTitle: The tenancy agreement states the tenant will vacate the rental unit or site at the end of the fixed term and I want an order of possession
106.selectionHelp: If you have a signed fixed-term tenancy agreement that requires the tenant to vacate at the end of the fixed term, you may select this issue. You may request possession during the tenancy if you believe the tenant may not move out as agreed. Please note that the law regarding the use of vacate clauses has changed effective December 11, 2017.
106.issueHelp: You must provide a copy of the signed tenancy agreement that clearly shows that the tenant must vacate the rental unit at the end of the fixed term and that clause must be initialled by both the landlord and the tenant. If the tenancy agreement is not provided or is not clear, then an arbitrator may decide that the tenancy will continue. Please note that the law regarding the use of vacate clauses has changed effective December 11, 2017.

111.selectionTitle: Do you want to include a request for the tenant to pay you back for the cost of the filing fee?
111.issueTitle: I want to include a request for the tenant to pay me back for the cost of the filing fee
111.issueHelp: The arbitrator will make a finding at the hearing to determine who should bear the cost of the application filing fee.  When calculating the total dollar amount do not include the cost of the filing fee.

114.issueTitle: I have another issue that is not listed

135.issueTitle: The landlord has eligible capital expenditures and is seeking an additional rent increase
135.issueHelp: A capital expenditure is eligible for an additional rent increase if it is for the purpose of installing, repairing or replacing a major system or component of the residential property. The expense must have been incurred within the last 18-months from the time this application is submitted. A capital expenditure does not include repairing damage caused by the landlord's neglect or failure to minimize the damage. Learn more about capital expenditures.

227.selectionTitle: A mutual agreement to end the tenancy was signed
227.issueTitle: A mutual agreement to end the tenancy was signed and I want an order of possession
227.selectionHelp: If you and the tenant have entered into a mutual agreement to end tenancy, you may select this issue.  You may request possession during the tenancy if you believe the tenant will not move out as agreed.
227.issueHelp: A mutual agreement can end a tenancy on any date that is mutually agreed upon. You must provide a copy of the signed mutual agreement to end tenancy.  If the mutual agreement is not provided or is not clear, then an arbitrator may decide that the tenancy will continue.

226.selectionTitle: The tenant has given written notice to end the tenancy
226.issueTitle: The tenant has given written notice to end the tenancy and I want an order of possession
226.selectionHelp: A tenant's notice to end a tenancy must be in writing to be effective and should include the tenant's name, date, address of the rental unit or site, the date that the tenant will be vacating and it must be signed.  The notice must provide for one clear rental month of notice.
226.issueHelp:
You must provide a copy of the tenant's written notice to end tenancy. If the tenant's notice is not provided or is not clear, then the tenancy may continue.

If the tenant's notice doesn't provide one clear rental month of notice,the effective date is automatically corrected to the allowable effective date and the tenant is required to pay rent until the effective date of the notice. For example, if the tenant gave notice on December 10th for December 31st, the effective date of the notice is corrected to January 31st and the tenant is responsible for payment of rent until the legal effective date of the notice.

107.textDescriptionTitle: Provide a complete list of the items you are requesting compensation for
107.selectionTitle: I want the tenant to pay to repair the damage that they, their pets or their guests caused during their tenancy
107.issueTitle: I want compensation for damage caused by the tenant, their pets or guests to the unit, site or property
107.selectionHelp:
Select this issue if you are requesting an order that the tenant pay for the cost of repairs for damage that they, their pets or their guests caused. This may also include the costs of cleaning at the end of a tenancy.

If you are asking to hold the security deposit or pet damage deposit to offset the claim, select that you want to hold the deposit below. You must provide evidence to prove that you are holding a deposit and that you have a right to claim against the deposit.
107.issueHelp: You must include all items for which you are applying for compensation and submit only relevant evidence to support your claim. Failure to list any items or provide evidence may result in those items not being considered. The total amount requested should reflect the complete total of all items listed. Any amounts claimed over the "Amount Requested" in the application may result in those amounts not being considered.

127.issueTitle: I want the tenant to pay to repair the damage that they, their pets or their guests caused during their tenancy - request to retain security and/or pet damage deposit
127.textDescriptionTitle: Provide a complete list of the items you are requesting compensation for
127.issueHelp: You must include all items for which you are applying for compensation and submit only relevant evidence to support your claim. Failure to list any items or provide evidence may result in those items not being considered. The total amount requested should reflect the complete total of all items listed. Any amounts claimed over the "Amount Requested" in the application may result in those amounts not being considered.

108.selectionTitle: I want to recover the money for the unpaid rent and/or utilities
108.issueTitle: I want to recover the money for the unpaid rent and/or utilities
108.selectionHelp: Select this issue for current rent that is unpaid.  If you are requesting to keep a security deposit to offset the unpaid rent, you must indicate that you are holding the deposit.
108.issueHelp:
You must provide evidence below to prove your monetary claim for unpaid rent and/or utilities.

Future rent losses may be claimed by selecting "I want compensation for my monetary loss or other money owed" below.

128.issueTitle: I want to recover the money for the unpaid rent and/or utilities - request to retain security and/or pet damage deposit
128.issueHelp:
You must provide evidence below to prove your monetary claim for unpaid rent and/or utilities.

Because you are asking to keep a security deposit and/or pet damage deposit to offset the costs, you may wish to include evidence to show the amount of the deposit you collected and when (usually on the tenancy agreement).

A pet damage deposit may only be used for damage caused by a pet.

Future rent losses may be claimed by selecting "I want compensation for my monetary loss or other money owed" below.

110.issueTitle: I want compensation for my monetary loss or other money owed
110.textDescriptionTitle: Provide a complete list of the items you are requesting compensation for
110.selectionHelp: Select this issue for compensation for any financial loss or other money owed.  This may include rental loss, strata fines, late fees or any other monetary loss that is not damage or unpaid rent.
110.issueHelp: You must include all items for which you are applying for compensation and submit only relevant evidence to support your claim. Failure to list any items or provide evidence may result in those items not being considered. The total amount requested should reflect the complete total of all items listed. Any amounts claimed over the "Amount Requested" in the application may result in those amounts not being considered.

208.selectionTitle: I want to dispute a 10 Day Notice to End Tenancy Issued for Unpaid Rent or Utilities
208.issueTitle: I want to dispute a 10 Day Notice to End Tenancy Issued for Unpaid Rent or Utilities
208.textDescriptionTitle: Describe why you are disputing the notice
208.selectionHelp: This notice is used if you fail to pay the full rent or utilities on the day they are due.  You have five days after receiving the notice to pay the outstanding rent or utilities in full or dispute the notice.  If you pay the outstanding rent or utilities in full within the five days, the notice is cancelled and the tenancy continues.
208.issueHelp:
Provide evidence to show that you have a valid reason for not paying the rent in full or that the rent was paid. The landlord must give you a written demand letter to pay utilities before issuing this notice for unpaid utilities, informing you of the amount of utilities owing, the due date and allowing you 30 days to pay the unpaid utilities.

You must submit your application with five days of receiving this notice. If you file your application too late, the landlord may request an order of possession. Verify that your dispute deadline has not passed.

Ensure you have read the information on the second page of the notice carefully.

You should provide evidence to show that the notice is not valid.

230.issueTitle: I want to dispute a 10 Day Notice to End Tenancy Issued for Unpaid Rent or Utilities and I need more time to dispute this notice
230.textDescriptionTitle: Describe why you are disputing the notice and why you are filing late
230.selectionHelp:
This notice is used if you fail to pay the full rent or utilities on the day they are due. You have five days after receiving the notice to pay the outstanding rent or utilities in full or dispute the notice. If you pay the outstanding rent or utilities in full within the five days, the notice is cancelled and the tenancy continues.

You have the right to dispute this Notice within five days after you receive it. An arbitrator may extend your time to file an Application, but you must provide proof of your serious and compelling reason to miss the deadline.
230.issueHelp:
Provide evidence to show that you have a valid reason for not paying the rent in full or that the rent was paid. The landlord must give you a written demand letter to pay utilities before issuing this notice for unpaid utilities, informing you of the amount of utilities owing, the due date and allowing you 30 days to pay the unpaid utilities.

You must submit your application with five days of receiving this notice. If you file your application too late, the landlord may request an order of possession. Verify that your dispute deadline has not passed.

Ensure you have read the information on the second page of the notice carefully.

You should provide evidence to show that the notice is not valid.
